Into concerts for the crowd.

People are happy when they stop
Chasing what they think they need,
And notice all the small miracles
Already planted like seeds.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent low beneath the weight of shame,
My spine curved like a question mark,
My voice a whisper without name.

I crawled through corridors of doubt,
On hands and knees through others' scorn,
My dignity a tattered cloak
That I had worn since I was born.

But seasons change, and so did I—
The earth beneath my palms grew warm,
I felt the strength within my bones,
The quiet power of the storm.

I lifted up my weary head,
Saw sunlight streaming through the trees,
And stood upon my trembling legs
Like ships that brave the restless seas.

No longer bound by others' words,
No longer small beneath their gaze,
I learned that grovelling was a choice,
Not written in my DNA.

The creature that I used to be
Still lives somewhere inside my chest,
A reminder of the depths I've known,
The darkness that preceded rest.

But now I walk with shoulders straight,
My footsteps firm upon the ground,
For I have learned that rising up
Makes the most beautiful sound.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Scraping belly against cold stone,
Eyes fixed downward, never daring
To claim a space I called my own.

I fed on crumbs of validation,
Starved myself on borrowed light,
Made apologies my daily bread,
Wore sorry like a second sight.

My words were whispers, barely there,
My dreams tucked deep in hidden drawers,
I made myself so very small
That I could slip through closing doors.

But metamorphosis is strange—
It happens when you least expect,
The day I caught my own reflection
And felt a flicker of respect.

Something ancient stirred within,
A wildness I had long suppressed,
The memory of what I was
Before the world had me compressed.

Now I unfurl like morning ferns,
Stretch limbs that once were cramped with fear,
My voice rings clear across the valley,
My presence solid, bright, and near.

The grovelling creature sleeps below,
A shadow-self I've left behind,
But grateful for the lessons learned
In darkness, before I learned to shine.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
My belly pressed against the dirt,
Each footstep overhead like thunder,
Each glance a blade designed to hurt.

I spoke in stammers, lived in corners,
Made myself invisible and small,
Believed that I deserved the shadows,
That I had no right to stand tall.

My dreams were kept in whispered prayers,
My hopes locked tight in secret rooms,
I bloomed only in the darkness,
A flower that expected gloom.

But time has teeth that gnaw at chains,
And pain can be a teacher too—
I learned that bowing down forever
Was not what I was meant to do.

The first time that I raised my chin,
The world did not come crashing down,
The first time that I spoke my truth,
I heard my own authentic sound.

Now when I see another soul
Bent low beneath their heavy load,
I offer them my steady hand
And share the secrets of this road.

For we were all grovelling creatures once,
Before we learned to trust our wings,
Before we knew that we were worthy
Of all the joy that courage brings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Belly pressed to muddy ground,
Swallowing words before they formed,
Making barely any sound.

I lived in spaces others left,
Fed on scraps of their attention,
Wore my smallness like armor,
Perfected self-diminution.

My apologies came automatic,
Sorry for the air I breathed,
Sorry for existing loudly,
Sorry for the space I needed.

I watched the world from underneath,
From corners where the light grew thin,
Convinced that this was all I merited—
This half-life I was living in.

But something shifted in the soil,
Some buried seed began to grow,
A stubborn root that pushed against
The weight of all I thought I'd know.

I felt my backbone straightening,
Vertebra by vertebra,
Until I stood at my full height
And saw how far I'd traveled far.

The grovelling creature still exists,
A fossil in my memory,
But now she serves as evidence
Of who I used to be, not me.

I've learned that rising isn't betrayal
Of the humble soul I was—
It's honoring her patient waiting
For the moment I'd stand up because.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Who begged for scraps of love and light,
My knees worn raw from constant kneeling,
My eyes afraid to meet another's sight.

I lived in the spaces between words,
In the pauses where others breathed,
Convinced my worth was measured only
By how little space I'd need.

The world seemed built for giants then,
And I, a mouse among their feet,
Scurried quickly past their shadows,
Made myself small and incomplete.

But something wild stirred in my chest—
Perhaps it was my mother's rage,
Or maybe just the simple truth
That I had turned another page.

The day I felt my spine unfurl,
Like fern fronds reaching for the sun,
I realized grovelling was a costume
That could be taken off, undone.

I shed that skin like snakes in spring,
Left it crumpled on the floor,
And walked into the blazing daylight
Through my own wide-open door.

Now when I meet that creature still
Living in another's eyes,
I whisper: "You are not your posture,
You are not your compromise."

For we are all recovering grovellings,
Learning how to stand up straight,
Discovering that our full height
Was always worth the wait.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent low beneath the weight of shame,
My spine curved like a question mark,
Eyes fixed upon the muddy ground.

I crawled through corridors of doubt,
My knees worn raw from genuflection,
Begging scraps from tables high above,
Content with crumbs and condescension.

But something stirred within my chest—
A ember that refused to die,
A whisper that grew bold and strong:
"You were not born to live this way."

I felt my vertebrae align,
Each bone a stepping stone to sky,
My shoulders squared against the wind,
My chin lifted toward the light.

The creature that I used to be
Still lives within my memory,
A shadow cast by who I was,
A reminder of the climb.

Now when I meet another soul
Who grovels in the dust below,
I offer not my pity, but
My hand to help them rise.

For we are all just creatures learning
How to stand, how to be free,
How to shed our smaller selves
And claim our dignity.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Scuttling through the undergrowth of fear,
My words mere whispers, apologetic sighs,
My dreams buried beneath "I'm sorry" and "excuse me."

The world seemed populated by giants
While I remained perpetually small,
Shrinking from confrontation,
Dissolving at the first raised voice.

I wore invisibility like armor,
Believing safety lived in silence,
That love was earned through self-erasure,
That worth was measured by compliance.

But seasons change, and so did I—
Not through some grand epiphany,
But slowly, like a flower learning
It has every right to bloom.

I discovered my voice had volume,
My thoughts had weight and substance,
My presence wasn't an intrusion
But a gift the world was missing.

The grovelling creature hasn't vanished—
She surfaces in moments of old panic,
But now I recognize her fear
And gently coax her toward the light.

I am still becoming,
Still unlearning the art of diminishment,
Still practicing the radical act
Of taking up the space I need.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Slithering through shadows cast by others,
My backbone made of wishbone fragments,
Breaking under the slightest pressure.

I fed on scraps of validation,
Hungry for approval's bitter taste,
My tongue well-versed in self-deprecation,
My pride buried in unmarked graves.

The mirror showed a stranger's face—
Eyes that never met their own reflection,
A mouth that smiled when hearts were breaking,
Hands that clapped for others' victories.

I memorized the art of shrinking,
Made myself small enough to fit
In spaces never meant for living,
In corners where the light grows thin.

But metamorphosis is patient work—
No butterfly emerges overnight.
First came the recognition:
This chrysalis had grown too tight.

I shed my skin of servitude,
Unfurled wings I'd forgotten how to use,
Discovered that my voice could carry
Beyond the walls I'd built around myself.

The creature that I was still whispers
In moments when courage feels too bold,
But now I know her name is Fear,
And I am learning to say No.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
My belly pressed against cold stone,
Tongue tasting dust and bitter earth,
Eyes never daring to look up.

I lived in shadows cast by others,
Fed on the scraps they left behind,
My voice a trembling, broken thing
That begged for mercy, not for justice.

The world towered above my head—
A kingdom built for standing tall,
While I remained forever prone,
Forever reaching from below.

I knew the texture of each floor,
The pattern of a thousand shoes
That stepped around my crumpled form
As if I were just debris.

My prayers were whispered to the ground,
My dreams were small and earthbound things:
Perhaps today I'd earn a smile,
Perhaps today I'd feel less pain.

But even creatures of the dirt
Can feel the pull of distant stars,
Can sense there's something more than this
Endless genuflection.

One morning, I felt my muscles shift,
My bones remember their true purpose,
And slowly—oh, so slowly—
I began to rise.

The view from here is different now,
Though sometimes I still feel the urge
To drop back down to what I knew,
To the familiar ache of smallness.

But I have tasted standing up,
And there's no going back to crawling.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
My soul worn thin as paper,
Apologizing for the space I occupied,
For breathing the same air as my betters.

I lived in the margins of my own life,
A footnote to everyone else's story,
My dreams folded small and tucked away
Like love letters never sent.

Each morning I practiced disappearing,
Perfected the art of being less—
Less loud, less bright, less troublesome,
Less human, more convenient.

I collected rejections like pressed flowers,
Treasured each dismissive glance,
Convinced that suffering was virtue
And silence was my greatest gift.

My prayers were negotiations with emptiness:
"Please let me matter, just a little,
Please let someone notice I exist
Without regretting that they did."

But transformation comes in whispers first—
A rebellious thought that refuses burial,
A moment when the mirror shows
Not what I lack, but what remains.

I began to practice taking up space,
To speak without permission,
To walk with purpose through the world
Instead of tiptoeing around its edges.

The grovelling creature lives in me still,
A scar that sometimes aches in rain,
But now she serves as compass,
Pointing toward what I'll never be again.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
**Rewind Life and Remember**

If I could turn the golden dial back,
Spin moments like a vintage track,
I'd pause at summer afternoons
When laughter danced to childhood's tunes.

Rewind life and remember when
Your grandmother's soft voice again
Would whisper stories by your bed,
Her gentle hand upon your head.

I'd slow the seconds, frame by frame,
Before the world grew strange and tame,
When every puddle held a sea,
And backyard trees were kingdoms free.

Remember how the morning light
Would paint your walls with colors bright,
How every day stretched endlessly,
A canvas of possibility.

The tape would crackle, voices clear
Of loved ones we no longer hear,
Their presence filling empty space
With memory's warm embrace.

But time moves forward, never back,
Though hearts may yearn for what we lack.
So hold these moments, let them shine—
Tomorrow's memories by design.

For life's not meant to be rewound,
But treasured in each sight and sound.
The present moment, here and now,
Is all we truly have somehow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
**When Memory Calls**

Rewind life and remember—
those three words echo like a prayer
whispered in the dark corners
of a restless mind.

What would you choose to see again?
The first kiss that tasted of summer rain,
or the last goodbye you didn't know
was final?

Perhaps the ordinary Tuesday
when nothing happened except everything—
coffee growing cold on the kitchen table,
your mother humming off-key,
sunlight catching dust motes
like tiny dancers in the air.

We carry these fragments
like sea glass in our pockets,
smooth and worn from handling,
each one catching light
when held up to remembering.

But here's the secret:
we don't need a machine
to travel backwards.
Close your eyes,
breathe in deeply,
and suddenly you're seven again,
building castles in the sandbox,
believing in forever.

Memory is the only time machine
that actually works,
though it changes the past
each time we visit,
painting it in softer hues,
erasing the sharp edges
until what remains
is not what was,
but what we needed it to be.

Rewind life and remember—
then step forward,
carrying the best of yesterday
into tomorrow's light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
**Fragments of Yesterday**

Rewind life and remember—
the command echoes through empty rooms
where photographs gather dust
and clocks tick backwards in my dreams.

I would return to September mornings
when coffee steam rose like prayers,
when your sleepy voice called my name
from beneath tangled sheets.

Remember the weight of your hand
in mine during that thunderstorm,
how we counted seconds between
lightning and thunder,
measuring the distance of danger
while feeling perfectly safe.

If I could spin the reel backwards,
I'd linger in the grocery store aisle
where we argued over cereal brands,
such beautiful, meaningless disputes
that felt like the end of the world
but were really just the beginning
of learning to love completely.

The film would show us dancing
badly in the kitchen,
socks sliding on linoleum,
your terrible singing drowning out
the radio's static melody.

But memory is a broken projector—
it skips and stutters,
shows the same scenes repeatedly
while others fade to black.

So I sit here with phantom sounds:
your keys jingling in the door,
footsteps on creaking stairs,
the whispered "goodnight"
that still haunts my pillow.

Rewind life and remember—
but some films are too precious
to replay,
too sacred to disturb
with the machinery of longing.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
**The Cassette of Years**

Rewind life and remember—
press the button with trembling fingers,
watch the spools turn counterclockwise,
unraveling decades like ribbon.

There: the sound of your father's laugh
before illness stole his voice,
the creak of the porch swing
where you solved the world's problems
over sweet tea and fireflies.

Fast-forward through the blur
of school bells and birthday candles,
stop at the moment you first
held your newborn daughter,
her tiny fist wrapped around
your index finger like a promise.

The static crackles between scenes—
arguments that seemed so important,
tears over boys whose names
you can't even recall now,
the day you thought your heart
would never heal from breaking.

But listen closer to the quiet tracks:
Sunday pancakes and crossword puzzles,
the ritual of bedtime stories,
your mother teaching you to braid
her silver hair before the mirror.

These are the songs worth saving,
the melodies that matter most
when the tape finally runs out
and silence fills the room.

Rewind life and remember—
not to live there,
but to carry the best notes forward,
humming them softly
as you write tomorrow's soundtrack.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
**The Time Machine in My Chest**

Rewind life and remember—
if only hearts came with buttons,
if only we could press pause
on perfect ordinary moments.

I'd go back to Tuesday mornings
when nothing spectacular happened:
you reading the newspaper aloud,
commenting on headlines
while I pretended to listen,
really just memorizing
the rhythm of your voice.

Remember how we used to fight
over the thermostat?
Such silly, sacred wars
that meant we shared a home,
shared the small irritations
that bloom into love
when viewed from distance.

The reel would show us
learning each other's languages—
how you take your coffee,
which side of the bed
holds your dreams,
the face you make
when concentrating.

But memory is selective film,
editing out the mundane magic:
grocery lists stuck to the fridge,
mismatched socks in the laundry,
the comfortable silence
of two people who know
they belong together.

Now I press rewind
on empty rooms,
watching shadows move
across familiar walls,
listening for echoes
of conversations
that shaped us both.

The machine keeps spinning,
but some moments refuse
to be captured—
they live in the space
between heartbeats,
in the pause before
"I love you,"
in the exhale
after coming home.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy when the morning light
Spills golden honey through their window panes,
When coffee steams and everything feels right,
And yesterday's worries wash away like stains.

People are happy in the smallest things—
A child's bright laughter echoing down the hall,
The way a favorite song suddenly sings
From radio speakers, making spirits tall.

They find their joy in unexpected places:
A stranger's smile while waiting for the train,
The warmth of sunshine kissing upturned faces,
The gentle rhythm of summer's cleansing rain.

People are happy when they choose to see
The magic hiding in the everyday—
In garden flowers blooming wild and free,
In friends who listen to the words they say.

But happiness isn't just what they receive;
It grows when kindness flows from heart to hand,
When they help others learn how to believe
That love still moves across this troubled land.

People are happy when they understand
That joy's not found in what they think they need,
But in the grace of simply where they stand,
And in their power to plant a hopeful seed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy in the spaces between—
Between the rushing and the standing still,
Between the dreaming and the waking scene,
Between the valley and the distant hill.

People are happy when they stop pretending
That perfection is the only worthy goal,
When broken hearts find ways of slowly mending,
And scars become the stories of the soul.

In crowded rooms or walking paths alone,
They discover happiness was always there—
Not in the things they thought they had to own,
But in the simple act of being aware.

People are happy sharing silent meals,
Watching storms roll across the evening sky,
Finding that what the restless spirit feels
Is peace in moments that don't question why.

They're happy in the mess of being human,
In tears that fall and laughter that erupts,
In all the ways that love keeps breaking through when
Life's careful plans get beautifully disrupted.

People are happy when they finally learn
That happiness isn't something to pursue—
It's in the breath, the pause, the slow return
To recognizing what was always true.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy when they stop searching,
When the endless quest for more finally ends,
And they discover joy was always lurking
In ordinary moments with ordinary friends.

People are happy dancing in their kitchens,
Singing off-key to songs nobody hears,
When worry's grip around their heart loosens
And they laugh until their eyes fill with tears.

They're happy watching clouds drift overhead,
Feeling grass beneath their bare, tired feet,
In conversations where nothing needs be said,
And silence feels perfectly complete.

People are happy holding sleeping babies,
Walking dogs through neighborhoods at dawn,
When life slows down from all its daily maybes
And they realize their anxiety is gone.

But sometimes people aren't happy at all—
They struggle through the darkness and the doubt,
Yet even then, if they listen for the call,
They find small lights that help them figure out

That happiness isn't constant sunshine;
It's learning how to dance between the rain,
To find the sacred in the mundane design,
And trust that morning always comes again.

People are happy when they stop pretending
Joy is a destination they must reach,
And start believing every day's worth defending
The simple truths that life is here to teach.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy in the grocery store,
Choosing ripe tomatoes, humming soft and low,
While children chase each other down each aisle,
And elderly couples move both sweet and slow.

People are happy on their morning runs,
Breathing in the crisp October air,
Their footsteps keeping time with beating hearts,
Wind tangling gently through their flying hair.

They're happy washing dishes after dinner,
Hands warm in sudsy water, minds at peace,
Remembering the laughter shared at table,
Feeling how small moments never cease.

People are happy reading bedtime stories,
Voices soft in lamplight's golden glow,
Watching little eyes grow heavy-lidded,
Knowing this is love in its purest flow.

They find their happiness in Sunday mornings,
Pancakes flipping, newspapers spread wide,
No rushing toward another obligation,
Just family gathered, sitting side by side.

People are happy when they stop to notice
How the light falls differently each day,
How their neighbor's garden blooms with color,
How their dog's tail wags in its own sweet way.

In these quiet, unremarkable moments,
Joy reveals itself without disguise—
Not in grand gestures or achievements,
But in the beauty of ordinary lives.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy when they let go of the weight
They've carried in their shoulders for too long,
When they stop trying to control their fate
And join the world's imperfect, perfect song.

People are happy in their grandmother's kitchen,
Flour dusting counters, recipes passed down,
Where stories mix with sugar and tradition,
And love is kneaded into golden brown.

They're happy watching thunderstorms roll in,
Safe behind windows while the wild wind howls,
Feeling small beneath the sky's vast din,
Yet somehow part of nature's sacred vows.

People are happy when they call old friends,
Voices bridging years and miles apart,
Discovering how true connection mends
The quiet loneliness within the heart.

They find their joy in bookstore browsing hours,
In libraries where silence holds such peace,
In gardens where they tend their growing flowers,
And watch their small anxieties release.

People are happy learning something new—
A language, instrument, or way to paint—
When curiosity breaks their routine through
And makes them feel both beginner and saint.

But mostly, people are happy when they choose
To see the light that lives in everyone,
When they stop keeping score of wins and lose,
And realize we're all just trying to become.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
**Metamorphosis**

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent double beneath the weight of shame,
My spine curved like a question mark,
Eyes fixed upon the muddy ground.

I scraped and bowed to every voice
That thundered from the heights above,
My words were whispers, pleas, apologies—
A symphony of self-erasure.

But something stirred within the depths,
A ember glowing in the dark,
Fed by every slight endured,
Every dream I'd pushed aside.

The fire grew, consuming fear,
Straightening my crooked bones,
Teaching me to lift my chin
And meet the world with steady gaze.

Now I stand upon the summit
Where once I crawled in valleys low,
My voice rings clear across the air—
No longer begging, but declaring.

The creature that I used to be
Still whispers from the shadows sometimes,
But I have learned the sacred art
Of rising from my own ashes.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I am becoming whole,
Each scar a testament to strength,
Each step a victory reclaimed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
**The Reckoning**

I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling through the corridors of power,
My tongue well-versed in flattery,
My knees worn smooth from genuflection.

I fed on scraps of validation,
Hungry for the smallest nod,
Trading pieces of my soul
For temporary sanctuary.

How easily I bent and broke,
A willow in the storm of others' wants,
My backbone made of wishes
And my heart of borrowed courage.

But time has teeth, and truth has claws,
And both have worked upon me well—
The mirror shows a different face,
One marked by years of compromise.

I see now what the price has been
For all that bowing and submission:
The self I might have been lies buried
Beneath the weight of false humility.

Yet in this recognition burns
A different kind of fire now—
Not rage, but something cleaner, sharper:
The will to excavate what's left.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But even broken things can heal,
And from the ruins of who I was
Something truer might emerge.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
**From the Dirt**

I was a grovelling creature once,
belly pressed against the earth,
tasting dust and disappointment,
swallowing words like bitter pills.

My hands knew only how to clutch
at ankles, hems, and trouser cuffs,
while my eyes mapped every texture
of boots that stepped around me.

The world existed far above—
a realm of light and laughter
where people walked upright
and spoke in voices I could barely hear.

I made my home in shadows,
in the spaces under stairs,
collecting crumbs of kindness
like a sparrow hoards its grain.

But seasons change, and so do souls.
One morning I discovered wings
I never knew were folded tight
against my shoulder blades.

The first flight was terrifying—
the ground so far below,
but oh, the view from up here
makes every grovel worth the climb.

Now when I see others crawling,
I remember how it feels
to believe the dirt's your ceiling
instead of just your starting place.

I was a grovelling creature once,
and sometimes still I am—
but now I choose my genuflections,
and they are acts of love, not fear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
**The Confession**

I was a grovelling creature once,
my spine a serpent's curve,
prostrate before the altars
of everyone but myself.

I wore humility like armor,
thinking smallness was a virtue,
that to disappear completely
was the highest form of grace.

My prayers were all apologies,
my dreams were whispered secrets
I dared not speak in daylight
for fear they'd be struck down.

I genuflected to opinions,
bowed before the crowd's approval,
made myself so very small
I nearly vanished altogether.

But somewhere in the grovelling,
between the dirt and degradation,
I found a pearl of understanding
buried in the muck of shame.

The earth I pressed my face against
was not my judge or jury—
it was simply earth, indifferent,
waiting for me to stand.

So I rose, not in rebellion,
but in quiet recognition
that the only god worth serving
was the truth within my bones.

I was a grovelling creature once,
and in that dark apprenticeship
I learned the weight of dignity
by knowing its absence first.

Now when I kneel, it's by choice,
and when I stand, I stand complete.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
**Resurrection Song**

I was a grovelling creature once,
my fingernails caked with earth,
scraping for approval in the dirt
while giants walked above my head.

I knew the taste of leather soles,
the texture of expensive shoes,
as I pressed my forehead down
and begged for scraps of recognition.

My vocabulary consisted of
"please" and "sorry" and "forgive me,"
a trinity of self-erasure
spoken in diminishing whispers.

I thought humility meant vanishing,
that grace required my disappearance,
so I folded myself smaller
until I was barely there at all.

But something wild lived in my chest—
a heartbeat that refused to quiet,
a pulse that drummed against my ribs
like fists against a prison door.

The day I felt it break free
was the day I tasted my own blood
and found it sweeter than submission,
richer than borrowed dignity.

Now I walk among the giants
not as equal, but as myself—
scarred by the journey upward,
but no longer afraid to bleed.

I was a grovelling creature once,
and that creature taught me this:
sometimes you must know the bottom
before you learn to climb.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

responses.text:
**Light Years Ago**

It seems like light years ago
when we danced beneath the stars,
your laughter echoing through space
like cosmic music from afar.

Time has stretched between us now,
vast as galaxies unfurled,
each memory a distant sun
in this ever-expanding world.

I measure moments not in days
but in the speed of fading light,
how long it takes for yesterday
to reach me in the endless night.

Your voice travels through the void,
a signal growing weak and thin,
while I orbit round the ghost
of everywhere we've ever been.

The universe keeps pulling us
to opposite ends of forever,
yet somewhere in the starlit dark
our paths might cross again, however

unlikely physics makes it seem—
for love defies the laws of space,
and though it seems like light years ago,
I still can see your shining face.

In dreams I close the distance fast,
collapse the years between hello
and this moment when I whisper:
"It seems like light years ago."

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

responses.text:
**When Light Years Collapse**

It seems like light years ago
since I believed in solid ground,
when gravity held meaning
and my feet knew where they'd found

their place among the certainties—
before the cosmos cracked apart,
before I learned that distance
isn't measured by the heart.

Now I drift through empty spaces
where our conversations used to live,
collecting fragments of your words
like stardust in a sieve.

The scientists say nothing
can outrun the speed of light,
but longing moves much faster
through the corridors of night.

I've aged a thousand lifetimes
in the span of one goodbye,
watched constellations rearrange
themselves across the sky.

Yet sometimes, in the silence
between one breath and the next,
I swear I feel you near me—
time and space become perplexed.

It seems like light years ago,
but maybe time's a trick we play
to make sense of the infinite
distance of a single day.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

responses.text:
**Distant Echoes**

It seems like light years ago
we shared the same small world,
when coffee shops and corner stores
were kingdoms we unfurled.

Back then, a week felt infinite,
a month stretched like a year,
and summer afternoons could hold
everything we held dear.

But now I count in decades
the moments since you left,
each season a small eternity
of feeling so bereft.

The photographs have yellowed,
the letters lost their scent,
yet still I feel the gravity
of everywhere we went.

Sometimes I catch your shadow
in strangers on the street,
or hear your voice in rainfall
making memories complete.

The distance isn't measured
in miles or months or tears,
but in the space between
what was and what appears.

It seems like light years ago
we promised "always" and "forever,"
not knowing time would teach us
that nothing lasts, however

beautiful the moment,
however strong the vow—
yet love transcends all distance:
you're light years away, but somehow
still here.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

responses.text:
**When Stars Were Young**

It seems like light years ago
that we believed in permanence,
when promises felt solid
and the future made perfect sense.

Back then our dreams were satellites
orbiting so close to earth,
we could reach up and touch them,
measure exactly what they're worth.

Now I'm floating in the darkness
between what was and what might be,
watching our shared history
drift away from me.

The messages you used to send
are radio waves in space,
still traveling through the cosmos
at their own unhurried pace.

Perhaps they'll reach some distant world
where other hearts are learning
that love creates its own time zones,
its own seasons of yearning.

I've become an astronomer
of moments we once shared,
mapping constellations
from the times when someone cared.

It seems like light years ago,
but maybe that's the point—
some distances are holy,
some separations anoint

us with a deeper knowing:
that light can travel far

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

responses.text:
**Light Years Ago**

It seems like light years ago
when your laughter filled the kitchen,
steam rising from morning coffee cups
and sunlight dancing through curtains
we hung together on a Saturday.

Now I measure distance
not in miles or months,
but in the space between
what was and what remains—
a universe expanding
with each breath I take alone.

Your voice echoes across galaxies
of memory, growing fainter
as I drift through days
that stretch like cosmic dust,
each moment a star
burning out before
I can wish upon it.

The photographs on my dresser
are ancient light, traveling
from a time when we existed
in the same constellation,
orbiting each other
with gravitational pull
so strong I thought
nothing could break free.

But here I am,
floating in the aftermath,
learning that some distances
can't be crossed by rocket ships
or prayers or desperate calls
at 3 AM when the silence
sounds too much like space—
infinite and unforgiving.

It seems like light years ago,
and maybe it was.
Maybe love operates
on its own timeline,
bending space around us
until forever becomes
just another word
for yesterday.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

responses.text:
**When Time Becomes Distance**

It seems like light years ago
since we believed in forever,

and we spent them carelessly,
rich with tomorrow's certainty.

The old neighborhood feels alien now—
familiar streets transformed
into foreign constellations
where I no longer know
the names of distant suns.

Your childhood bedroom,
once our secret universe,
now exists in another dimension
where sixteen-year-old versions
of ourselves still whisper
plans that never came to pass.

I drive past the movie theater
where we shared our first kiss,
but it's been demolished—
replaced by a parking lot
that stretches like empty space
between what happened
and what we thought would happen.

Time isn't linear here;
it bends and warps around loss,
making minutes feel like millennia
and decades collapse
into the span of a heartbeat.

Sometimes I catch myself
calculating the distance:
how many conversations,
how many shared meals,
how many "see you tomorrow"s
lie between then and now?

It seems like light years ago
because it was—
measured not in miles
but in the speed
at which innocence travels
away from us,
leaving only the faint glow
of what we used to believe
was permanent as starlight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

It seems like light years ago

Now I'm older, wiser,

The coffee shop where we planned

But somewhere in the space

It seems like light years ago

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

It seems like light years ago

The woman I was feels like

Before I Knew What Mattering Meant."

It seems like light years ago

one moment you're crawling
through the familiar darkness,

It seems like light years ago

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Blanketing earth in silence deep,
Where once green meadows danced with clover,
Now crystal drifts in slumber sleep.

The cities hushed beneath white veils,
Their bustling streets turned soft and still,
While winter writes her quiet tales
On windowpane and distant hill.

Each flake a whisper from the sky,
A frozen kiss upon the ground,
They dance and swirl and multiply,
Without a single earthly sound.

The trees stand draped in silver lace,
Their branches bent with gentle weight,
While children press against the glass
To watch the world transform its face.

It snowed and snowed through day and night,
Erasing all the world once knew,
Until the dawn revealed a sight
Of endless fields of pristine blue.

In this cathedral made of white,
Where footsteps leave the only prayer,
We find a peace both pure and bright,
A holy hush beyond compare.

The whole world sleeps beneath the snow,
Dreaming dreams of spring's return,
While winter's gentle blessings flow
And in our hearts, wonder burns.

The first emerged on Tuesday's dawn,
With downy fluff like morning's yawn.
By week's end, seven more had come,
A feathered choir, their voices hum.

The nest swayed gently in the breeze,
High up among the maple trees.
Eight open beaks reached toward the sky,
As parent birds went soaring by.

I watched them grow from day to day,
Their colors bright in nature's way—
Some speckled brown, some silver-gray,
Some marked with gold like sun's first ray.

The bravest learned to spread his wings,
While others clung to safer things.
But courage comes to those who wait,
And soon they'd meet their flying fate.

One autumn morning, crisp and clear,
The nest stood empty—none were here.
Eight birds had found their destined flight,
Beyond my window, out of sight.

Yet in my heart they'll always be,
That precious sight I chanced to see—
Eight birds that hatched in one small nest,
A memory I'll always treasure best.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**What Remains**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a river carved its song,
The summer's heat and absent rain
Have left us counting what went wrong.

In shallow mirrors, sky reflects
On water warm as morning breath,
While minnows dart in small defects
Between the stones of living death.

The heron waits with patient grace,
Her stilted legs like question marks,
As dragonflies embroider space
Above these final liquid arcs.

Children's laughter echoes still
From deeper days when currents ran,
When water rushed to meet the mill
And floods obeyed no earthly plan.

But in these pools, life persists—
Tadpoles dream of legs to come,
Water striders write their lists
On surfaces that catch the sun.

Perhaps tomorrow clouds will break
And pour their mercy from above,
Perhaps the sleeping streams will wake
And flow again with ancient love.

Until then, in what remains,
We learn that even smallest things
Can hold the memory of rains
And all the hope that waiting brings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**The Last Oasis**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
In this desert of forgotten dreams,
Where memories once fell like rain
And hope flowed bright in silver streams.

The drought of years has taken hold,
Our conversations turned to dust,
The stories that we used to fold
In laughter now lie thick with rust.

Yet here, in these remaining wells,
I find the fragments of our past—
A joke that still rings like bells,
A moment that was meant to last.

The water's warm but crystal clear,
Reflecting faces we once knew,
And though the end feels drawing near,
These pools still shimmer, deep and true.

A lizard drinks at water's edge,
Untroubled by the vast expanse
Of emptiness beyond this ledge—
He takes his simple, grateful chance.

So I will kneel beside these few
Small sanctuaries of the heart,
And drink what sweetness filters through
Before the final pools depart.

For even in the barren land,
These precious drops still catch the light,
And teach me how to understand
That something beautiful survives the blight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:

Of what we thought would never end—

A child crouches by the edge,

The pools hold secrets, small and bright:

So let me sit beside what's left
And watch the light dance on the surface,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:

Where cattle once came down to drink,

Now herons stand like sentinels

The farmer walks his withered land

Yet in these pools, so warm and small,

Perhaps the rains will come again
To fill these empty beds with song,
Until then, what we have has been
Enough to help us carry on.

In scarcity we learn to see
The precious worth of what remains,
And find in small pools by the tree
The beauty born of earthly pains.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**After the Flood**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of what the storm brought yesterday,
The rushing torrent's wild refrain
Now whispers soft, then fades away.

Where muddy waters roared and churned
Through streets and yards in chocolate streams,
Small mirrors catch what light has earned
Its way through dissipating dreams.

A rubber ball bobs, bright and red,
Beside a shoe that lost its mate,
While earthworms surface from their bed
To navigate this liquid fate.

The children, banned from deeper play,
Crouch close to watch the minnows dart
Through puddles that will drain away
Before the next storm's beating heart.

In gutters lined with autumn leaves,
The last of flood's great gift collects,
Each pool a story that believes
In water's power to connect.

Soon sun will drink these remnants dry,
Return the earth to thirsty dust,
But for this moment, you and I
Can witness what the heavens thrust

Upon our ordinary ground—
These temporary lakes of grace
Where sky and earth have briefly found
A common, shimmering embrace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Blanketing earth in silent white,
Each flake a whispered prayer of winter,
Dancing down through endless night.

The cities slept beneath the cover,
Their bustling streets now hushed and still,
While forests donned their crystal armor,
And snow crowned every distant hill.

Children pressed against cold windows,
Watching magic fill the air,
As snowflakes spun their ancient stories,
Weaving dreams beyond compare.

The world transformed in quiet splendor,
Sharp edges softened, harsh lines blurred,
Nature's gentle hand had painted
A masterpiece without a word.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Until the earth forgot its scars,
And in that pure and pristine moment,
We glimpsed the peace that could be ours.

When morning broke on fields of diamonds,
The sun kissed every crystal bright,
And though the snow would surely melt,
We'd carry with us winter's light.

For in that storm of silent beauty,
We learned what stillness truly means—
Sometimes the world must pause and listen
To hear the song of quiet dreams.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
As if the sky had torn apart,
Releasing all its frozen sorrow
Upon each weary, beating heart.

The flakes fell thick like scattered ashes
From fires that burned in distant lands,
While mothers clutched their children closer,
And fathers worked with frozen hands.

The wealthy watched from heated windows,
Their breath not misting in the cold,
While others huddled under bridges,
With stories that would not be told.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Erasing borders, blurring lines,
The storm cared nothing for our kingdoms,
Our flags, our walls, our grand designs.

In villages and sprawling cities,
The same white silence settled down,
Reminding us that we are equal
Beneath winter's thorny crown.

The snow revealed our shared fragility,
How thin the walls we build for warmth,
How quickly nature's indifference
Can humble our most cherished forms.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A lesson written in the white:
That we are small beneath the heavens,
And precious in our fleeting light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:

The power lines sagged heavy-laden,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy,
the world becomes a watercolor painting,
soft edges bleeding into brighter hues.
My footsteps dance on ordinary pavement
as if it were a stage of polished marble,
and every stranger's face holds secret stories
I want to hear over coffee and laughter.

When I am happy,
time moves like honey—
slow and golden, sweet to taste.
The morning light through my window
isn't just sunshine anymore,
but a personal invitation
to join the day's grand celebration.

When I am happy,
my heart grows three sizes larger,
making room for all the small miracles:
the way my cat purrs against my chest,
how steam rises from my tea cup
like tiny prayers ascending,
the perfect weight of a good book
in my hands.

When I am happy,
I remember that joy
isn't a destination to reach
but a lens through which to see—
transforming the mundane into magic,
turning Tuesday into a festival,
making me believe
that perhaps the universe
conspired specifically
to create this moment,
this breath,
this beautiful, fleeting now.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy,

through my eyes, my smile,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

they'll never send—
because happiness demands

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

The world feels wide enough

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**The Last Waters**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a river carved its way,
Reflecting fragments of the sky
In mirrors cracked by summer's reign.

The cattails stand like sentries thin,
Their roots clutching the muddy shore,
While dragonflies on gossamer wings
Dance above what was before.

A heron waits with patient grace,
Its shadow long across the stone,
For silver fish that dart between
The memories this place has known.

Children's laughter echoes still
From summers when the water ran

But seasons turn and rains grow sparse,
The earth drinks deep what little falls,
And what remains grows precious now—
These pools that hold it all.

In morning mist they catch the light,
Small sanctuaries, crystal-clear,
Reminding us that even drought
Cannot make beauty disappear.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Yet in their depths, the world reflects:
How precious water, life, and time—
How sacred what the heart protects.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**What Remains**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
In the desert of my mind,
Where thoughts once flowed like rushing streams
Now barely trickle, hard to find.

The drought began so quietly—
First words would slip away,
Then faces blurred like watercolors
Bleeding in the rain.

My daughter visits every week,
Her eyes bright pools of care,
She speaks of things I should recall
But find no longer there.

The nurse is kind, her voice is soft,
She helps me find my way
Back to the dining room at three,
Though I forget by day.

But in these pools, these precious few,
Some memories still shine:
Your wedding dress, our first dance,
Your small hand holding mine.

The taste of strawberries in June,
The sound of children's play,
The way you hummed while making bread
On any given day.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
But oh, how deep they run—
These fragments of a lifetime lived,
These echoes of the sun.

I'll guard them like a treasure chest
Until my final breath,
These pools of light, these drops of love
That conquer even death.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

Through waters that will soon be gone,

Beyond these temporary doors.

The sun climbs higher, drinks its fill
From mirrors lying crystal still,
Each pool a window to the sky
Where clouds like memories drift by.

Soon pavement will emerge once more,
Dry and dusty as before,
But for this moment, magic dwells
In temporary wishing wells.

The earth exhales its grateful breath,
Rescued from the threat of death,
While flowers lift their thirsty heads
From newly watered garden beds.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of last night's wild and cleansing rain,
Yet in their brief and shining hour
They hold the storm's transforming power.

By noon they'll vanish without trace,
But leave behind a blessed space
Where wonder lived, however brief,
In pools of joy and sweet relief.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**After the River**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
where once the river carved its song,
silver ribbons turned to stain
on cracked earth that waited too long.

Minnows circle in their shrinking worlds,
their universe condensing daily,
while cattails stand like flags unfurled
above the mud that spreads so gaily.

A heron visits, steps with care
around the edges of what's left,
its patience sharp as morning air,
of flowing water now bereft.

Children's voices echo still
from summers when the current ran,
when diving deep was just a thrill
and drought was not yet in the plan.

The stones lie naked, smooth and white,
like bones of some forgotten beast,
while memories of water's might
grow dimmer as the pools decrease.

But in each puddle, life persists—
water striders dance their ballet,
dragonflies keep their ancient trysts,
hope pooling in each small display.

Perhaps the rains will come again
to fill these hollows, heal the seams.
Just a few dwindling pools remain,
but in them swim tomorrow's dreams.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**The Last Oasis**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
in the garden of my grandmother's mind,

like koi breaking water's skin.

She remembers my name on Tuesdays,
forgets it by Thursday's end,

"Tell me about the roses," I ask,
and suddenly she's twenty-five again,

The pool of that memory runs deep—
she describes each bloom's perfume,

on petals like tiny prayers.

But then the water level drops,

"Who are you?" she whispers,
and I become a stranger again.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
of the woman who raised me,
yet in their shallow depths
I glimpse the ocean she once was—

vast, generous, life-giving,
before time's relentless drought
left only these precious remnants

I sit beside her, patient as a heron,

that surfaces in the diminishing pools

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**Remnants**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
where children once splashed and played,
their laughter echoing off concrete walls

Just a few dwindling pools remain
of what we thought would last—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**The Drought's End**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
scattered across the valley floor,
like teardrops from a sky in pain
that cannot weep much anymore.

The oak trees stand with brittle leaves,
their roots probing deeper still,
while dust devils dance through the eaves

Cattle gather at the edges
of these mirrors to the sun,

An old farmer checks his fences,

when water flowed through his defenses

But even now, in morning light,

how life adapts, holds on tight,
makes scarcity its faithful tool.

For in the smallest puddle's gleam,

proving that hope's not just a dream

The earth knows how to wait and heal,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**What Remains**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
of us, scattered like forgotten coins
across the landscape of our love—
here, where you laughed at my terrible joke,
there, where we fought about nothing
and everything all at once.

I visit them like a pilgrim,

in water that grows shallower each day.

The pool where you first said you loved me
has nearly dried to dust,

where those words once rippled out
in circles that seemed infinite.

The deeper one, where we planned our future,
still holds enough to see the bottom—

beneath the surface, unchanged
but somehow smaller now.

Your absence is the drought
that draws these waters down,
leaving salt rings on the banks
to show how high we used to reach.

But even in the smallest puddle,
something of us still survives—
a minnow-flash of shared laughter,
the reflection of your smile
caught for just a moment
before the ripples take it away.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
but oh, how clearly they remember
the river we once were.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
A mirror of what I might be—
Not flesh and bone, but shadow-light,
A figure born of inner sight.

She wears my face but holds it strange,
As if time's river carved the change
Between the self I think I know
And truths that in the darkness grow.

Her eyes reflect what mine have missed,
The dreams I've buried, chances kissed
Goodbye before they could take root,
The songs I silenced, staying mute.

Before me stands I see the cost
Of every path I never crossed,
Each word unspoken, love unfelt,
Each moment where my courage melt.

Yet in her gaze burns something bright—
Not judgment harsh, but gentle light
That whispers soft across the space:
"There's beauty still in your embrace."

She reaches out with phantom hand
To help me finally understand
That what I see is not my foe,
But all the ways I yet might grow.

Before me stands I see at last
Not prison walls built from my past,
But doorways opening to the dawn
Where new and truer selves are born.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
A stranger wearing yesterday's clothes,
Dust motes dancing in the space between
What was and what still grows.

The morning light cuts sharp and clean
Through windows I forgot to close,
Revealing truths in golden beams—
How little, really, anyone knows.

Before me stands I see the weight
Of choices made in whispered haste,
The phantom limbs of old mistakes
That time has failed to fully erase.

But look—there in the shifting air,
Something moves with quiet grace,
A possibility taking shape,
A future finding its own place.

The floorboards creak beneath my feet
As I step toward what I cannot name,
This vision born of morning's heat
That calls me forward just the same.

Before me stands I see the door
Between the person I have been
And who I'm meant to be—
The threshold where my life begins.

The stranger nods and steps aside,
No longer blocking out the sun.
Before me stands I see the path
Where ending and beginning run as one.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
A question mark carved from the air,
A riddle wrapped in morning mist
That shouldn't rightfully be there.

The grammar bends, the meaning shifts
Like water poured through broken glass—
These words that tumble, rearrange
Themselves as moments slowly pass.

Before me stands—but what? And where?
I see—but seeing what, exactly?
The sentence fragments, incomplete,
Yet speaks to something more abstractly.

Perhaps it's how we always look
Upon the world with fractured sight,
Our language failing to contain
The fullness of what meets our light.

Before me stands I see the gap
Between intention and the word,
The space where meaning comes undone
And truth becomes a thing half-heard.

Or maybe in this strange refrain
Lives poetry's essential art—
To break the rules of sense and sound
And speak directly to the heart.

Before me stands I see the proof
That beauty needs no perfect form,
That broken phrases, like broken hearts,
Can shelter us from reason's storm.

The line repeats, insistent, strange:
Before me stands I see, I see—
A mantra for the mystery
Of what it means to simply be.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
The echo of my mother's voice
Calling from the kitchen door,
A sound that time cannot destroy.

The scent of bread and summer rain
Mingles with the dust of years,
While shadows dance on wooden floors
Where laughter lived, and sometimes tears.

Before me stands I see the child
I used to be, with muddy knees
And pockets full of treasured stones,
Who climbed the tallest apple trees.

Her eyes hold secrets I've forgotten,
Adventures buried under grown-up things,
The magic that made cardboard boxes
Into castles fit for kings.

She points beyond the fading light
To where the fireflies begin their show,
Reminding me that wonder waits
In places I've forgotten how to go.

Before me stands I see the truth—
That innocence need never die,
It simply waits behind the veil
Of all our reasons, all our why.

The child extends her tiny hand
And whispers soft as evening breeze:
"Come play with me in yesterday,
Where every moment aims to please."

Before me stands I see the bridge
Between who I was and who I am,
A golden thread that leads me home
To where my truest story began.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
A paradox in flesh and bone—
The stranger who shares my reflection,
Yet walks a path I've never known.

Her footsteps echo mine but different,
Each stride a choice I didn't make,
She turns left where I turned right,
Spoke truth where I chose silence for politeness' sake.

Before me stands I see the woman
Who said yes when I said no,
Who packed her bags at twenty-three
And let the restless wind blow.

Her hands are calloused from adventures,
Her laugh rings wild and free,
While mine grew soft from playing safe,
From being who I thought I ought to be.

She wears my face but bolder,
My voice but raised in song,
My heart but unafraid to break,
My spirit but twice as strong.

Before me stands I see the proof
That every moment holds a door,
That who we are is just one note
In life's unfinished score.

She smiles and starts to fade away,
But leaves behind a gift—
The knowledge that it's not too late
To let my own life shift.

Before me stands I see myself
As I could still become,
If I have courage to step forward
Into the life I've been running from.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**The Last Waters**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a river carved its way,
Reflecting fragments of the sky
In mirrors cracked by summer's reign.

The herons that once waded deep
Now pick through shallows, stepping light
On stones that knew the current's song
But now lie bare in harsh daylight.

Children's laughter used to ring
Across these banks where willows grew,
Their branches trailing in the flow
That carried dreams and paper wings.

The cattails stand like sentinels

Yet in these pools, life persists—
Minnows dart through liquid glass,
Water striders write their names
On surfaces that will not last.

Perhaps the rains will come again
To fill these hollows, heal the land,
Or maybe this is how it ends—
With just a few pools, grain by grain.

The earth remembers what we've lost,
Each puddle holds a history,
A testament to what once was,
A prayer for what still yet might be.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**Remnants**

Just a few dwindling pools remain

She remembers making bread at dawn,

But names slip through her fingers now

The pools grow smaller every day,

I cup these precious drops of her

That echoes in the empty space

Just a few dwindling pools remain,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**After the Drought**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where salmon once fought upstream,

Like fragments of a shattered dream.

The old-timers speak in whispers
Of springs that never used to fail,
Of creeks that ran year-round and deep,

Now children dare each other

A bridge of fallen timber logs—
The crossing that their fathers feared.

Beneath the cracked and thirsting earth
Lie bones of ancient waterways,
Ghost rivers mapping out the paths
Of long-forgotten, greener days.

The cottonwoods stand skeletal,
Their roots reaching ever down
To find the water table's gift
Beneath this sun-baked, hardpan ground.

But evening brings the herons still,
Patient in their vigil kept,

Where promises are somehow kept.

For water always finds a way

Just a few dwindling pools remain—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**What Remains**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of what we used to call forever—
Those promises we carved in stone
Now worn smooth by time's rough weather.

The photographs have lost their color,
Faces fading into sepia dreams,
While voices echo in empty rooms
Like water trickling through the seams.

Your coffee cup still holds its place
Beside the window where you'd sit,
A monument to morning rituals
That death could never quite permit.

The garden struggles without your hands,
Wild roses climbing past their bounds,
Yet somehow in this sweet chaos
Your careful love still can be found.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of all the words we never said,
Collecting in the quiet spaces
Between the living and the dead.

But pools can nurture hidden life—

And in these remnants of our love
New understanding takes its form.

So let me kneel beside these waters,
Cup them gently in my palm,
And drink the essence of what was
To find in loss a healing balm.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**Tidal Memories**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Along the shore where we once played,
Left behind by the retreating tide
In hollows that the waves have made.

I search among the scattered shells
And seaweed tangled, dark and wet,
For treasures that the ocean left—
Small tokens I can't quite forget.

A hermit crab scuttles past,
Seeking shelter in the brine,
While sandpipers on stick-thin legs
Dance along the water's line.

The sun beats down on shallow pools,
Each one a world complete and small,
Where sea anemones unfurl
Like flowers on a garden wall.

Children's voices drift away
As families pack and leave the beach,
But I remain beside these pools
Where ocean's secrets I can reach.

The tide will come again tonight
To claim these temporary seas,
And wash away the tiny worlds
That formed between the rocks and trees.

Yet something in these pools endures—
The salt, the life, the endless flow
That connects each drop of water
To depths we'll never fully know.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
But in their mirrors I can see
The vast and endless ocean's heart
Still beating wild and strong and free.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy,
the world unfolds like origami wings,
each crease a memory of laughter,
each fold a promise kept.

When I am happy,
colors taste like childhood summers—
strawberry sunsets on my tongue,
lemonade light dancing through windows
that frame my grandmother's smile.

When I am happy,
I become a collector of small miracles:
the way coffee steam writes prayers
in morning air, how strangers' dogs
wag their entire bodies at my approach,
the perfect weight of a book
settling into my palms.

When I am happy,
time moves like honey,
thick and golden, worth savoring.
I notice the architecture of clouds,
the secret conversations between
wind and leaves, the way
my heartbeat syncs with
footsteps on familiar streets.

When I am happy,
I remember that joy is not
a destination but a practice—
like learning to catch light
in cupped hands, like teaching
my shadow to dance,
like writing love letters
to the ordinary world
that holds us all.

When I am happy,
I am home.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

When I am happy,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy, the world turns golden bright,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**After the Drought**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a river carved its name
Through valleys green and meadows wide,
Now cracked earth spreads on either side.

The heron stands on spindly legs,
A statue where the water begs
For rain that may not come this year,
While minnows dart in liquid fear.

Children's laughter used to ring
Across these banks each early spring,
Their bare feet splashing, voices bright,
Now echoes fade in failing light.

The willows droop their thirsty hair
Into the pools with tender care,
Their roots reach deep through hardened clay
For moisture that has slipped away.

Yet in these mirrors, small and still,
Life persists against its will—
Water striders dance their waltz,
While dragonflies patrol like ghosts.

Perhaps tomorrow clouds will break
And give this thirsting land a shake,
Fill the channels, heal the scars,
Reflect again the moon and stars.

But for now, just pools remain,
Holding hope through sun and pain,
Teaching us that even small
Reserves of grace can save us all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**The Last Sanctuaries**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
In the cathedral of my memory,
Where your voice once rippled
Through conversations deep as oceans.

Now I wade through shallow remnants—
A laugh caught in amber afternoon light,

These small reservoirs hold everything:

I am the careful curator
Of these diminishing waters,
Rationing each precious drop
Against the drought of your absence.

Sometimes I kneel at their edges
And see your face reflected back,
Distorted but unmistakably you,
Shimmering in the surface tension.

The desert advances daily,
Sand claiming what was once fertile,
But I guard these final pools
With the devotion of a monk.

For in their depths lie proof
That love, once deep and flowing,
Leaves traces even when it's gone—
Just a few dwindling pools remain,

But they contain entire worlds.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**Remnants**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of what we used to call our dreams—
Those grand ambitions, bold and bright,
Now scattered like forgotten streams.

I count them in the morning light:
One holds my childhood's fearless heart,
Another cradles songs unsung,
The third keeps hope and doubt apart.

The desert of reality
Has drunk the rivers of our plans,
Left only these small sanctuaries
Cupped gently in time's weathered hands.

My mother's voice still echoes here
In one small pool beside the oak,
Her stories ripple through the years
Though she herself has long since spoke

Her final words. The water's clear
But shallow now, I must bend low
To catch the whispered wisdom there
That once ran deep, helped gardens grow.

The neighbors say come autumn rain
These pools will fill and overflow,
Connect again in rushing streams
That carve new paths where flowers grow.

But I have learned to love these pools,
These concentrated drops of grace—
Sometimes the smallest bodies hold
The deepest truths we'll ever face.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
And that, perhaps, is quite enough.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**The Tide Pools**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
After the storm surge pulled away,

Where ocean secrets choose to stay.

In one, a starfish clings to stone,

The children gather, voices hushed,

An anemone blooms green and gold,

Through coral gardens, smooth as metals.

The sun climbs higher, water warms,

Balanced on the very brink.

Soon waves will crash and claim them back,
Restore what storm and tide have taken,
But for this moment, pools remain—

I kneel beside this fleeting gift,

And learn that beauty often lives
In spaces torn and set apart.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Yet each one holds infinity.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**What the Desert Remembers**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of the lake that kissed these hills,

Of bass that jumped at sunset's call,

Now jackrabbits claim the basin,

Where sailboats danced in days before.

But here and there, like secrets kept,
Small mirrors catch the desert sun—
Remnants of what used to be,
Proof that abundance once was won.

A roadrunner pauses, drinks deeply,
Then darts away on spindled legs,

A coyote howls, a mourning begs.

The pools grow smaller every day,
Yet still they offer what they can—
A sip of hope, a flash of sky,
The memory of a greener plan.

In drought we learn what matters most:
Not the vastness we have lost,
But the precious drops that linger,
Sacred, small, and tempest-tossed.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
But they remember everything.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**What Remains**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a river carved the stone,

The herons that would wade and fish

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**Remnants**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of what we used to call forever—
Those promises we made in May
When love felt deep as any river.

The drought came slowly, then all at once,
Words unsaid became the silence,
Touch withdrew like morning mist,
Leaving only small islands of remembrance.

In these shallow waters, I can see
The ghost of who we used to be:
Two figures dancing in the rain,
Believing we could never drain

Would always, always endure.

But even now, these tiny pools
Reflect the sky we shared above,

Through the remnants of our love.

Perhaps this is how endings come—
Not floods that wash away the past,

Just a few dwindling pools remain,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
**Drought's Testament**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
where salmon once fought upstream,
their silver bodies now just stories
the old fishermen tell at dawn.

The riverbed lies naked,
exposing secrets—
rusted shopping carts,
a child's bicycle,
love letters in bottles
that never reached their destination.

Egrets stand like sentries
guarding what little water survives,
their white wings folded
in patient prayer.

The mayor speaks of conservation,
of trucking water from distant lakes,
but the pools shrink daily
under the merciless August sun.

Mrs. Chen brings her grandchildren
to see where she learned to swim,
pointing to dry rocks and saying,
"Here, the water was over my head."

The children nod politely
but cannot imagine
this wasteland ever flowing,
ever singing the old songs.

Still, in the deepest pool,
a single trout circles endlessly,
its fins worn thin from years
of swimming in smaller and smaller circles.

We watch it through the clear water,
this last witness,
this keeper of the river's memory,
this stubborn proof that something
always survives
even when everything else
has learned to let go.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

**The Last Gardens**

Just a few dwindling pools remain
In grandmother's forgotten yard,
Where koi once swam in lazy circles
And lily pads spread like green prayers.

The fountain stopped its singing
When the pump gave up last spring,
But rainwater still collects
In the carved stone basins,
Creating accidental sanctuaries
For the brave and small.

A robin comes each morning
To bathe in the shallowest pool,
Sending ripples across the surface
That catch and scatter sunlight
Like broken promises of abundance.

The neighborhood has changed—
Condos where the orchard stood,
Parking lots where wildflowers
Once painted the hillside purple.
Progress, they call it,
This careful erasure of the wild.

But here, in these remnant pools,
Mosquito larvae dance their brief ballet,
Water beetles trace ancient patterns,
And somewhere beneath the algae,
The ghost of goldfish still glimmers.

I kneel beside the largest pool
And see my face reflected back—
Older now, lined with years
Of watching things disappear.
Yet in this water's memory
Lives everything we've loved:
The splash of children's laughter,
The patient heron's morning visit,
The way light moved through leaves
To dapple the surface gold.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
But they hold entire worlds.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

The old oak stood with crystal branches,

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,

In morning's hush, the world lay dreaming,

The snow fell still, as if to cover
All the wounds that time had made,
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Until all sorrows gently fade.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'
